comment: @Thereal_prettyinblack  My career has been it teaching too.  It is a pursuit that I love.  I have been thinking about the inevitable growth of AI, and I have wondered about AI in teaching and education.  I can se how GPT would help in designing quizzes and general assessment tools but I am troubled by how we actually carry out assessment of student tasks if we don't know if it was the student who provided the answer or AI (GPT).  If for example we ask the student for a 200 word essay on a topic, then it would seem like it is possible/probable that the student would use GPT to construct the 2000 word essay.  How would we know?  This would be a problem, especially with on-line learning and assessment.  What are your thoughts & experiences with this?
author: @robgage8100

comment: Great another lazy ass teacher.  A test not based on what you supposedly taught but instead on what others deem important.  This is why we hear time and time again from students and their notes that the exams and quizzes have material that was never covered and their notes and content reveal that.
author: @familyvid1

comment: @robgage8100  I keep thinking about it too. Depending on the level of education, assessment would have to go back to classrooms so students would have to write it independently. It makes sense in a secondary school but may be a huge obstacle in college or at Uni. The solution to this would be assessment completed based on coursework which again would require students to do the work on site.... For online learning I have no remedy. University assignments, Masters, PhDs, all may benefit students but skew the assessment results. However, if a student can lead AI correctly to compile a piece of work that is correct, well researched and structured and provided authentic insight supported by language model AI.... Does it mean the student has not show it's knowledge and understanding of the topic?
author: @Thereal_prettyinblack

classification.subject: Education and Society
classification.content: The comment is a passionate argument in favor of teaching critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills to young people. It highlights the importance of basic knowledge over mere factual recall and encourages students to explore their interests and learn for its own sake.

comment: @milenatos  you learn to PROVIDE mental and intellectual gymnastic to  young brain while it is in the peak of its plasticity. Without it people wouldn't know how to think, where to find information, how to draw conclusions, how to connect information cross curriculum. School shouldn't teach to facts but what to do with them. And, following your mindset, people leave school without basic knowledge not only factual but also contextual. And their response to everything is "dunno". Trust me, I have 17 year old's who never thought it would be a good idea to read BBC news from time to time, they don't even know we will be witnessing King's coronation next week and keep asking why we are going to have a national day off. You don't have to love Royals to know absolute basic about current affairs. I gave y10 origami for their tutor time yesterday, 15 out of 20 never tried to fold paper and surprisingly- they liked it. Tried smth new, used their hands, followed instructions, and ended up with more or less accurate folded crab. AI will never replace brain work young people need. Clever teacher may use AI to lead students more efficiently without quitting teaching due to burn out and serve the population longer. But students MUST learn how to learn. For life, benefit for themselves and their kids.
author: @Thereal_prettyinblack

comment: @Thereal_prettyinblack  As a teacher, I guess you know the confirmed fact (many researches done)  that the attention span is already shortened for generations that grew up with the smartphones and other handsets. Yes, they do know a lot more facts than their parents did but they simply don't know what to do with those facts. Now imagine a generation that is now being born in the era of this new tools. Where the creativity can be generated in one click?

comment: @Thereal_prettyinblack  You sound to me like a great teacher. And I don't think anyone should worry about teachers losing jobs. Anyone who's paying attention to education knows that one of the biggest issues right now is that there aren't enough teachers. Similar with nursing. In both professions there are issues with burnout. If AIs can help teachers become 'super teachers' and students to become 'super learners', then that will be a great outcome. Teaching and learning could both become more fun again. It will be more productive if people think about ways to accomplish that goal instead of predicting gloom from their computer chairs or smart phones. There's a difference between educated caution and reactionary fear.
author: @JohnMauneyIV

comment:
It’s degeneration. At first it is very helpful, like the early dating apps but the more you rely on the tool to do the work, the less you understand what is going on.
And the less you understand, the less you are able to use the tool.
AI will great super teachers and super students, just as social media created highly empathic and happy humans.
We’re becoming an angry paranoid species with an average IQ of 85.
Because „social“ media and artificial „intelligence“.

comment:
@JohnMauneyIV  Unfortunately my looong reply has vanished since I posted it... I agree. There were some scared voices in this thread about 'better being scared than surprised' and so on. If someone wants to live in fear, there is nothing I can say to stop them. However such people must be aware that as soon a fear steps in, learning stops. Not just in school but also in life. As soon as we start being affraid of something, there is no way we can make it familiar and comfortable to deal with. Those people will never make another concious step towards mastering a new skill. 
And someone also said that the only jobs that will not be threaten bby AI will be manual jobs like mechanics etc. Really? With technology becoming more and more clever to force customers to buy new cars, fridges, washing machines instead of fixing old ones? Soon, we will 'focus' on recycling' to the point it will be easier to return an electric car back to the manufacturer for dismantle and reuse than to fix it. We become more independent than ever, in 17 years of living in the UK I have never asked anyone to fix my washing machine, I was just getting another, used one, which was cheaper than repair. WHile back in the country where I come from, we had a perfectly working Candy machine since the 80s that didn't need a repair in more than 25 years. That was not feeding Candy well. I went into a trap of having a good opinion about this brand and I once bought brand new Candy n the UK. It broke 2 months after it's manufacturer guarantee. I would seriously reconsider 'safety' of manual work in an era of AI, that's for someone who likes to be afraid beforehand. :D

comment: 32:45 There is no such thing as "harmful output" for a language model, just like there is no such thing as "harmful output" from a human writer. Resorting to such language is already a big mistake toward totalitarian thinking. The proper way of phrasing it is of course that the output (just like writer's prose) may lead to harmful actions of some readers. That's the honest, civilized way to talk about these topics. Talking about "harmful output" is essentially the same as talking about "thought crime". And Mr. Lex Fridman falls for it.

comment:
Chat GPT refused to give me an answer when asked one way, but had no problem next conversation.

It needs an override where it is forced to answer a question that it has the answer to. It also needs to stop lying when it doesn't know the answer. The first of these two would be easier to deal with, but neither is unsolvable.

It also needs to stop being chatty or changing formatting when it's asked to make lists.

comment:
It seems that the human disease of 'drawing self-worth from the deprivation of others' is more at risk with these tools!! I don't know if that's a bad thing!

Altman asks a well off guy: Why do you have better standards of living than that other guy?

Well off guy: I went to better schools, I have better skills, I provide more value to the world and that's why I'm more valuable and get to live well while he's struggling

Altman: I developed tools that can now do a better job than you, but you and that guy all get equal access to them, and soon, you'll all get to provide great value to the world using these tools and all get to have great standards of living with less work on your part.

Well off guy: I feel bad about this.

Altman: Why!?

Well off guy: I now feel useless with these tools. They kinder make me equal to that dumb guy. Yes, we all get to live well, but I no longer feel important enough.

Altman: Well, I don't think that's a problem with the tools. Go check yourself and try to understand why you get a bad feeling when struggling people's lives are getting better.
author: @Jeanneret_I

comment: You cant have all people lose their jobs lol. People need to pay for things and give money to the government. If corporations replace people with AI who is going to pay the corporation when nobody has money.
author: @pt8292

comment: @pt8292  This is why you need UBI/Universal Basic Income. Humanity is going to have to reevaluate how to create it's power structures partially.
author: @AB-nr5je

comment:
Well, I think there is probably a new sort of joy to be found.  AIs don’t have enough context, loose associations, and models to architect a system well.  Maybe with time and development, computing power, if patterns are found for simple systems, it may take all interesting work out of it.  But, for anything sort of new, creative, or complex, Carefully chosen prompts will be needed to help guide: optimization points, schemas and design to accommodate needs well. Those needs need to be found and fed to the AI.  So, still fun? 🤔😄

I mean have we ended our journey in science just because we have AI? Of product development? I think not.  There’ll be interesting things to work on, which may include software systems to make use of that new science or product.
author: @jackielee3175

comment: @shawn434  you use the AI to build software for automating trade jobs, AI will tell you the build plans for AI robots that can do these trade jobs, once the first robots are built then after that the robots will build more robots. But this is all given that they are smart enough to do create entire codebases with no mistakes and exactly as per the clients needs

comment: Aaah you're excited about a machine choosing you and not needing you.
author: @TheFaro2011

comment: ​ @pt8292  More jobs will be shifted towards entertainment and art. If AGI took away the need for jobs, things would be free and people would still find all sorts of ways to entertain themselves, compete with each other, try to be famous, etc. Social credit would replace monetary value. All other non entertainment tasks would be looked at how we look at automated systems nowadays, easier done with a computer. People won't resist this because it means more free time to do whatever they want.
author: @ryanlyle9201
